Technical Assistance Report
 
 
 
Project Number: 54350-001 
Knowledge and Support Technical Assistance (KSTA) 
December 2020 
 
 
Strengthening Digital Information of the National 
Statistical Data Systems 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
This document is being disclosed to the public in accordance with ADB’s Access to 
Information Policy.

ABBREVIATIONS 
 
  ADB  –  Asian Development Bank 
  CAPI  –  computer-assisted paper interviewing 
  CATI  –  computer-assisted telephone interviewing 
  CAWI  –  computer-assisted web interviewing 
  DMC  –  developing member country 
  ERCD  –  Economic Research and Regional Cooperation Department 
  EROD-SDI  –  Statistics and Data Innovation Unit 
  NSD  –  national statistical data 
  NSO  –  national statistics office 
  OP  –  operational priority 
  SDMX  –  statistical data and metadata eXchange 
  SDG  –  Sustainable Development Goal 
  TA  –  technical assistance 
  TASF  –  Technical Assistance Special Fund 
 
 
NOTE 
 
In this report, "$" refers to United States dollars. 
 
 
  
Vice-President  Bambang Susantono, Knowledge Management and 
Sustainable Development  
Chief Economist and  Yasuyuki Sawada, Economic Research and Regional 
Director General  Cooperation Department (ERCD)

SDI), ERCD

EROD-SDI, ERCD

ERCD

ERCD 
Stefan Schipper, Senior Statistician, EROD-SDI, ERCD 
Eric Suan, Associate Statistics Officer, EROD-SDI, ERCD 
 
 
In preparing any country program or strategy, financing any project, or by making any designation 
of  or  reference  to  a  particular  territory  or  geographic  area  in  this  document,  the  Asian 
Development Bank does not intend to make any judgments as to the legal or other status of any 
territory or area.

1 
I.  INTRODUCTION 
 
1.  The knowledge and support technical assistance (TA) will support capacity enhancement 
of the national statistical data (NSD) systems of selected developing member countries (DMCs) 
in Asia and the Pacific to produce high-quality statistical information using modern technology, 
innovative data, advanced methods, and best practices. The Statistics and Data Innovation Unit 
(EROD-SDI) of the Economic Research and Regional Cooperation Department (ERCD) has 
undertaken capacity building initiatives in statistics, and this project, as one of those initiatives, 
supports  the  Sustainable  Development  Goals  (SDGs)  through  technology-focused  capacity 
building, in line with Strategy 2030 of the Asian Development Bank (ADB).1 The project is aligned 
with operational priority (OP) 6 of Strategy 2030 (strengthening governance and institutional 
capacity) as it will enhance the capacity of statistical systems to produce information needed for 
evidence-based policy making and program monitoring. Statistics produced in participating DMCs 
will enable governments and ADB to track progress in alleviating poverty, in line with Strategy 
2030 OP1 (addressing remaining poverty and reducing Inequalities). The project also supports 
OP7 of the strategy (fostering regional cooperation and integration) in that it will encourage 
country- and sector-specific participation in global statistical standards and methodologies. The 
TA is part of the approved workplan of ERCD and will enable ADB to expand its socioeconomic 
databases used for critical analysis.2 
 
II.  ISSUES 
 
2.  High-quality  data  that  can  be  transformed  and  analyzed  are  needed  to  deliver  the 
indicators in Strategy 2030 which can improve policy making, monitoring, and accountability of 
DMCs. In a globalized and digitalized world, relevant, accurate, timely, cross-cutting, readily 
accessible, and usable statistical information based on conventional and innovative data are 
critical to analyzing local and global socioeconomic issues. The use of modern technology, 
cutting-edge methods, and innovative data can significantly improve the quality and usability of 
statistics in, for example, formulating policies, and tracking progress toward development goals—
especially the SDGs, which ADB recommends using to guide recovery from the coronavirus 
disease (COVID-19).3 
 
3.  Although NSD systems in the target DMCs4 produce key socioeconomic indicators and 
even compile crucial data relevant to the SDGs, they have failed to adopt technological and 
technical innovations in the field of statistics and continue to compile statistics through outdated 
and/or costly means, which adversely affects the quality and timeliness of data. Furthermore, 
traditional data-release and dissemination methods severely limit the accessibility and usability of 
data. These shortcomings leave these NSD systems unable to provide critical and timely data. 
The selection of the DMCs will vary and will be broadly based on the following criteria: the DMCs 
(i) will be conducting a census, survey, administrative, or nontraditional data; (ii) should have 
qualified staff who can be trained in statistics; and (iii) should be keen to incorporate modern tools 
and statistical innovations into their systems. 
 
 
1 ADB. 2018. Strategy 2030: Achieving a Prosperous, Inclusive, Resilient, and Sustainable Asia and the Pacific. Manila. 
2 The TA first appeared in the business opportunities section of ADB’s website on 4 November 2020.  
3 ADB. 2020. Use SDGs and Paris Agreement to Guide Recovery from COVID-19 - ADB VP. Bangkok. 
4 Target DMCs are those classified in group A (concessional assistance-only) and those in group B and C that have 
identified the subject matter of this TA project as areas for further development in their respective NSD systems 
(https://www.adb.org/sites/default/files/institutional-document/31483/om-a1.pdf). Furthermore, based on this criteria, 
EROD-SDI already have a tentative list—e.g. Pacific countries.

2 
4.  The TA project will focus on innovative approaches to producing key socioeconomic and 
SDG-relevant statistics in two domains: (i) data collection, management, and dissemination; and 
(ii) knowledge sharing on innovations in statistics.  
 
III.  THE TECHNICAL ASSISTANCE 
 
A.  Impact and Outcome 
 
5.  The TA is aligned with the following impact: DMCs’ capacity to produce, manage, and 
exchange  information  in  support  of  rigorous  evidence-based  policy  making  and  program 
monitoring, particularly in relation to the SDGs, enhanced. The TA will have the following outcome: 
Capacity of DMCs’ NSD systems to produce, manage, and disseminate high-quality, high-
frequency, and granular statistics on selected socioeconomic indicators strengthened. 
 
B.  Outputs, Methods, and Activities 
 
1.  Collection, management, and dissemination of data through innovative 
technology 
 
6.  Output 1: Developing member countries’ statistical capacity in using computer-
assisted personal interviewing, computer-assisted telephone interviewing, or computer-
assisted web interviewing enhanced. Under this output, ADB will support at least two DMCs to 
facilitate implementation of a survey based on computer-assisted personal interviewing (CAPI), 
computer-assisted telephone interviewing (CATI), or computer-assisted web interviewing (CAWI). 
The national statistics office staff of the targeted DMCs will be trained in all aspects of these 
surveys, including questionnaire design; programming on CAPI, CATI, or CAWI platforms; data 
validation; data transfer; and maintenance of relevant equipment or devices. Furthermore, training 
will be provided on the use of software to collect data using tablets, telephones, and/or the web. 
 
7.  Output 2: Workshops on latest developments in the field of surveys conducted for 
developing member countries. As the availability of high-speed internet expands in DMCs, so 
does the opportunity to pilot novel surveying techniques such as interactive voice response, short 
messaging service (SMS) surveys, and opinion polling using social media. The TA will support 
ADB staff and DMC officials and researchers to participate in workshops to promote knowledge 
sharing on technological innovation in surveying. 
 
8.  Output 3: Statistical data and metadata eXchange standards adopted by developing 
member countries. The TA will support selected DMCs to implement statistical data and 
metadata eXchange (SDMX)—an International Organization for Standardization (ISO) standard 
to describe statistical data and metadata, normalize the exchange of such data, and promote 
efficient sharing of such data across organizations.  
 
2.  Knowledge sharing on technological, technical, and data innovations in 
statistics 
 
9.  Output  4:  Online  training  provided  to  developing  member  countries  on  using 
information and communication technology tools to improve collection and management 
of survey data. ADB in partnership with the Food and Agriculture Organization of the United 
Nations launched two massive open online courses on CAPI that saw high enrollment in 2019 
and 2020. Given the high demand from DMCs for skills in digitized surveys, the TA will support 
updating these two massive open online courses to reflect the latest version of the software for

3 
providing  such  courses,  and  to  include  additional  modules  on  telephone,  interactive  voice 
response, SMS, and web interviewing. 
 
10.  Output 5: Online course on statistical data and metadata eXchange developed for 
the developing member countries. ADB in collaboration with SDMX sponsor organizations will 
develop a free online course to train DMC officials and staff on modern data dissemination 
according to the latest international standards. 
 
11.  Output 6: Developing member countries’ participation in knowledge-sharing events 
on statistics supported. Support provided to DMC researchers and ADB staff to participate in 
international conferences, seminars, and workshops on statistics and related subjects to enhance 
their technical and technological capacity and promote knowledge sharing on topical issues.5 
 
C.  Cost and Financing 
 
12.  The TA is estimated to cost $750,000, which will be financed on a grant basis by ADB’s 
Technical Assistance Special Fund (TASF 6—$445,000 and TASF-other sources—$305,000). 
The key expenditure items are listed in Appendix 2.  
 
D.  Implementation Arrangements 
 
13.  ADB will administer the TA. ERCD, through EROD-SDI, will be the executing agency. The 
TA team will consult with ADB’s Information Technology Department in procuring equipment, 
software, and other information technology-related needs of the project. ADB’s Department of 
Communications will provide inputs to support the publication of knowledge products. EROD-SDI 
will also explore potential areas for collaboration with ADB’s Sustainable Development and 
Climate Change Department. As a focal point of the SDGs, the Strategy and Policy Department 
will be regularly updated on the TA activities.  
 
14.  Implementation arrangements are summarized in the table.

international or multilateral organizations. EROD-SDI will be the executing agency for output 6 and will make all 
necessary arrangements for participants.

15.  EROD-SDI will implement all activities relating to knowledge-sharing workshops, training, 
and preparation of technical reports under the TA; while the national statistics offices will be the 
national implementing agencies for all country-specific case studies and activities. No activity will 
be financed in any participating DMC unless the DMC government provides a no-objection letter.6 
All TA activities will be implemented from December 2020 to December 2023.  
 
16.  Consulting services. The TA will finance 242.5 person-months of consulting services 
(14.5  person-months  international  and  228  person-months  national).  ADB  will  engage  the 
consultants following the ADB Procurement Policy (2017, as amended from time to time) and its 
associated project administration instructions and/or staff instructions.7 EROD-SDI will consider 
lump-sum payments and output-based contracts for consulting services. 
 
17.  ADB’s procurement. EROD-SDI will procure survey data and other forms of data from 
DMC  agencies  and research  institutions  and may  also  procure  equipment  such  as  laptop 
computers and software for the TA where needed. Procurement will follow the ADB Procurement 
Policy (2017, as amended from time to time) and its associated project administration instructions 
and/or  staff  instructions  (e.g.,  shopping  method).  For  equipment,  EROD-SDI  and  national 
 
6 In addition to no-objection letters, a framework of partnership, which is a non-legal yet formal document outlining the 
detailed roles and responsibilities of ADB and participating DMCs and schedule of key milestones and activities 
(including estimated cost of activities), will also be signed. A draft framework of partnership will be provided to the 
Office of the General Counsel and other relevant departments for review prior to signing by both parties.  
7 Terms of Reference for Consultants (accessible from the list of linked documents in Appendix 3).

5 
statistics offices will submit a certificate of equipment turnover or disposal to the Office of 
Administrative Services at the end of TA implementation.  
 
18.  Social  media  and  websites.  EROD-SDI  will  coordinate  with  the  Department  of 
Communications and the Information Technology Department to promote on ADB’s social media 
accounts and website the online courses and training materials produced by the TA team. 
 
IV.  THE PRESIDENT’S DECISION 
 
19.  The President acting under the authority delegated by the Board, has approved the 
provision of technical assistance not exceeding the equivalent of $750,000 on a grant basis for 
Strengthening Digital Information of the National Statistical Data Systems. This action is hereby 
reported to the Board.

Key Activities with Milestones 
Data collection, management, and dissemination through innovative technology

1.3 Mobilization and hiring of consultants (Q4 2020)

2. Workshops on latest developments in the field of surveys conducted for DMCs 
2.1 Mobilization and hiring of consultants (Q4 2020) 
2.2 Training workshops on the latest developments in the field of surveys (Q1 2021–Q4 2023)

ADB = Asian Development Bank.  
a Financed by ADB’s Technical Assistance Special Fund (TASF 6 and TASF-other sources).  
b Includes airfare and miscellaneous travel expenses, and shall be implemented in accordance with the memorandum 
Travel Expenses of Consultants under TA and Government Officials in Connection with Non-Member Countries dated 
29 October 2013.  
c Includes copyediting, proofreading, and other publishing-related activities and/or support.  
d Includes cost of data purchase, field surveys, and other data collection.  
e Includes procurement of information technology-related hardware, equipment (e.g. laptops and computers), and 
software; survey purchase; and data support.  
f The Statistics and Data Innovation Unit (EROD-SDI) of the Economic Research and Regional Cooperation Department 
(ERCD) is the executing agency and will be responsible in the engagement of the resource persons and facilitators.  
g Covers travel cost of ADB staff as resource persons, dissemination activities, and modest representation at reasonable 
cost (Project Administration Instructions 5.09, para. 26). 
h Either EROD-SDI (executing agency) or implementing agency (e.g. NSOs) will facilitate the arrangements for the 
venue rental and related facilities needed for training and workshop.  
i Will support the participation of at least 20 officials, researchers, and/or academics from the developing member 
countries identified in para. 15 of the technical assistance report.  
j Per para. 26 of Project Administration Instructions 5.09, this should be kept at a minimal level, and the government 
should follow ADB’s guidelines on representation provided in Administrative Order 4.03 on representation and the 
guidelines for field offices’ beverage services subsidy. The Technical Assistance Supervising Unit is responsible for 
verifying and validating the eligibility and reasonableness of the cost.
